glossary.item: Making notes directly onto a text such as a book, a handout, or another type of publication.
An objective summary includes only factual information from the original source and does not include the emotional or biased opinions.
Meanings determined by the reader which may not be explicitly stated in the text.
A translation or interpretation.
The dictionary definition of a word; the literal, precise or exact meaning of a word.
The figurative definition of a word; the intended message that accompanies the word, regardless of the denotative meaning.
A documented list of sources.
Features or characteristics.
Grown and expanded.
The way language is intentionally used for the purpose of persuasion.
The use of logos, ethos and pathos in writing.
Provides or establishes credibility.
Provides emotional appeal.
Provides useful or logical information.
Placed near each other.
Mood; a general quality, effect, or atmosphere.
Original documents, photographs or interviews.
Information that was interpreted by someone else.
Viewpoints or translations.
To draw a conclusion based on what you have read.
Insults.
Beared; put up with.
In such a way that there can be no retaliation.
Non remedied.
Retaliation.
Habit.
Craziness.
Becoming the victim.
Approached with hostility.
Colorful clothing.
A cone-shaped hat with bells at the end.
A type of wine.
Cloak of knee length.
A large home or mansion.
Torches.
Vaults or tombs.
Mucous.
A class or category of literature.
Types or kinds.
A large cask measuring 80 gallons.
Restrained or chained.
A sword.
This type of essay discusses literary elements, such as symbolism, imagery, figurative language, as well as the themes developed within the literature
The thesis is the one statement that summarizes the entire point of your essay.
Modern Language Association
The way in which words or phrases are put together to create meaning.
A way of responding to people who may not agree with your claim.
Writing for academic purposes.
Words used within writing to make it cohesive and easier to understand for the reader.
An expert in knowing the details and differences of wine.
a white powdery mineral.
The central idea or topic of a piece of text.
The time and location in which a story takes place.
The difference between what seems to be and what is real.
An expression or remark that is meant to be rude or undermining.
The solution to the conflict; the end of a story.
Writing to inform or explain a topic.
Writing that tells a story, with a clear beginning, middle, and end.
Writing that makes a claim and backs it up with evidence.
Details used by the writer to engage the readers sense of smell, taste, sound, touch, and sight.
Quotations that show up in the middle of your paper without being introduced.
This device refers to the way that the personalities of characters are developed and revealed to the reader.

Multiple levels of conflict may exist within one novel. There may be inner conflict, whereby a character battles his or her thoughts or emotions, or external conflict where characters battle against some outside force or action.
Similes, metaphors, and analogies are used to make comparisons of one or more objects to something else for the purpose of adding some emotion or tone to the object.
An author will use flashback to provide insight into current events, to let a reader know the background information leading up to some other event or action.
A foil is a character who has exact opposite character traits of a different character.
Hints are provided about events that are yet to come.
Vivid and concrete details are provided to describe exactly what characters see, hear, feel, and do.
Events occur which are the opposite of what the characters and/ or readers would have expected to happen.
This refers to who is telling the story.
One object stands as a depiction of some other object or idea which has a very different literal meaning, although the symbolic meaning is implied.
The reason that an author has written a particular article, document, or piece of literature.
A reference to a published or unpublished source.
A quotation directly from a source that is integrated into the writing.
Using your own words to explain the main ideas of the material you are borrowing.
Using your own words to retell the ideas; shorter than a summary.
Using the exact words from the source to explain your own point.
Thesis or the main point the writer argues.
Opposing viewpoint; disagrees with the claim.
What you need to know. Background information is presented, main characters are introduced, and the conflict is established.
The conflicts and challenges encountered by the characters. How they respond keeps the story moving forward.
The turning point in the conflict. Tension builds until the main character must make a decision or take action that determines the direction of the story.
The events that occur after the main character makes the key decision in the story.
The resolution is where all the questions are answered and loose ends are tied, providing a clear ending.
No one attacks me with impunity.
Container of wine with a name similar to "grave".
Suddenly yelled or exclaimed.
Rest in peace.
Just a number
